story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsAs more rivers, reservoirs and wells go dry across Bundelkhand, Annie Banerji meets some of the 600 ‘Jal Sahelis’ trying to fix the region’s perennial water woesClick to followThe IndependentHer face veiled, Kiran Aherwal shovels&nbspgravel into a broad platter, places&nbspit on her head, then steps&nbspoff to help construct a new check&nbspdam in her thirsty village in central India.Years of drought and water scarcity have often led her children&nbspto go hungry, she says – but she aims to change that.As more rivers, reservoirs and wells go dry across Bundelkhand – a parched region of 20 million – Aherwal has joined about 600 “Jal Sahelis”, or water women friends, to try to fix the region’s perennial water woes.The women – up to three in each of more than 200 villages – galvanise their communities to harvest rainwater, dig wells, de-silt ponds, build check dams and repair hand pumps.The women say their efforts have resulted in better irrigation, healthier crop harvests, increased drinking water and, most importantly, fewer long walks to fetch water.Created with Sketch.Indian city Chennai running out of water Show all 12Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Puzhal reservoir in Chennai, India before the drought and in its current state meaning millions of people are turning to water tank trucks as house and hotel taps have run dryIndian workers collect water from the Puzhal reservoirThe drought is the worst in living memory for the bustling capital of Tamil Nadu stateIndian residents get water from a community well in Chennai after reservoirs for the city ran dryPeople sit around a tower for measuring water depth in the dried-up Puzhal reservoirIndians stand in queues to fill vessels filled with drinking water from a water tanker in ChennaiA man walks through the dried-up Puzhal reservoir,Puzhal reservoir in Chennai, India before the drought and in its current state meaning millions of people are turning to water tank trucks as house and hotel taps have run dryIndian workers collect water from the Puzhal reservoirThe drought is the worst in living memory for the bustling capital of Tamil Nadu stateIndian residents get water from a community well in Chennai after reservoirs for the city ran dryPeople sit around a tower for measuring water depth in the dried-up Puzhal reservoirIndians stand in queues to fill vessels filled with drinking water from a water tanker in ChennaiA man walks through the dried-up Puzhal reservoir,“During summers, we have to get water from about 5 kilometres away. When there isn’t enough water, I can’t even make food on time or feed my children,” says Aherwal, 28, who became a Jal Saheli in her village of Agroutha in April.“This will help solve our water problem. Our village will be able to drink water. We will get to irrigate our crops again.”One of India’s biggest cities has almost run out of waterIn earlier times, Bundelkhand, blighted by 13 episodes of drought in the last two decades, received 52 days of rainfall a year. But the number of days has more than halved since 2014, according to Skymet Weather, a private weather forecasting agency.That has led to repeated and widespread crop failures in a region&nbspthat is dependent on agriculture, prompting a growing tide&nbspof farmers to migrate to nearby cities.Women and children often bear the brunt of water shortages – from domestic violence as tensions rise in water-short homes to missed&nbspschool days and child marriage, according to local water conservation&nbspexperts.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailIt is common to find veiled women, carrying up to four pots – some balanced on their heads – walking miles with their children&nbspto fetch water several times a day.With their vision obstructed, there are times they trip and drop&nbsptheir pots, forcing them to go back for refills.Bundelkhand region&nbsp(AFPGetty)“We used to get so tired fetching water,” says Tara, a Saheli in Manpur village who goes by one name.“Sometimes we would say ‘Ok, we didn’t wash our clothes today, we will do it tomorrow’ or ‘I didn’t bathe today, maybe tomorrow’. That’s how bad it was.”But things have changed since 2016 after Tara and two other Sahelis talked about the need for water conservation in their village and gathered dozens of people to revive their community pond and wells, and install new hand pumps.We see ads on TV that show water flowing from taps, from showers and think ‘Wow, we should move to the city’. But that is a false dream, at least for people like us who have no money. So it is better to make changes hereNow washing dishes, cooking, mopping, doing the laundry, bathing, farming and taking care of livestock are much easier, says&nbspGeeta, another Saheli who goes by one name.“If there is water, we have everything and if there is no water, we have nothing,” she says, gesturing to Manpur’s brimming pond where buffaloes wallow&nbspto beat the heat.Rural Indian women make good managers and protectors of natural resources, says&nbspReetu Sogani, a researcher on traditional knowledge, gender and climate change.“Because they interact so closely with their natural surroundings and they know what kind of problems they face in day-to-day life ... they come up with solutions and adaptation mechanisms based on their knowledge,” she says.For many women, it hasn’t been easy to become Jal Sahelis in a male-dominated, conservative region, where age-old customs dictate a woman’s life.“My husband got upset and asked ‘Why are you going out?’&nbsp’Where are you roaming around?’ ... ‘You aren’t even getting paid, what is the point?’,” says Aherwal, who makes up to 6,000 rupees (£70) a month rolling traditional cigarettes at home.“I endured all his anger, his scoldings to join this group.”Several Sahelis say their husbands and in-laws eased up after noticing the water situation&nbspimproving – and the women weren’t cutting corners at home.Dargai Khurd village (AFPGetty)After their chores and work at home, most women can carve out only two hours a day for their Saheli work, they say.That can involve creating a water conservation plan for their village, participating in local council talks, meeting government officials, and learning how to use tools to fix wells and hand pumps – a chore traditionally done by men.Sanjay Singh, the secretary of Parmarth Samaj Sevi Sansthan, a grassroots charity behind the Jal Saheli programme, says the women are now more involved in household and village decisions, leading to effective change in some places.“The index of happiness has increased (in the region),” he says.Everything you need to know about getting rupees and visas for IndiaKashmir on lockdown after India reimposes curfew and deploys troopsIndia orders schools to reopen, but Kashmiri parents keep kids at homeBindrawan Lodi, a 60-year-old farmer, agrees. He says without the Sahelis’ push to revive their community pond, his Chaukheda village would have been in “a lot of trouble”.“This place was bone dry. Now we have enough water to irrigate our crops. Drinking water is still a struggle ... but this is a start,” he says.Bundelkhand, once a region green with dense forests and fields, is increasingly barren with little groundwater.The area’s rocky terrain largely stops rainwater from percolating&nbspinto aquifers, Singh says. Loss of forests also has hit&nbsprainfall, and water reservoirs have sometimes been used wastefully, residents say.Although civil society and government agencies have ramped up water conservation efforts, Singh warns that&nbspmuch more needs&nbspto be done before the “dangerous” effects of climate change exacerbate problems of unemployment, malnutrition and migration.Two in five people in rural Bundelkhand have become urban migrants over the last decade, according to estimates by activists from the Bundelkhand Water Forum, a coalition of local organisations.Singh says more private investment, bigger government budgets, work restoring trees and other greenery and climate adaptation techniques, such as growing less water-intensive crops, could help stem the exodus.That is one of the reasons&nbspthe Sahelis say&nbspthey work so hard. They want to ensure their children can stay put and their daughters or daughters-in-law can live a life free of water worries.“We see ads on TV that show water flowing from taps, from showers and think ‘Wow, we should move to the city’. But that is a false dream, at least for people like us who have no money. So it is better to make changes here,” says Aherwal.“Our village will become beautiful in the next five years. title: school summer holidays 2019 start end dates
story: Here are the key dates you need to know for the   academic year...Most schools in the UK are heading back at the beginning of September after their summer break, though somein mid-August.The new autumn term - which sees pupils move up a year - typically runs from Monday, September , , until Friday, December , .These dates will y depending on the school and you are advised to check your schools website.The period includes half term, which is from Monday, October , to Friday, October , .Dates y depending on your school, so be sure to check your schools website for exact dates.Schools break up for the autumn half term on Friday, October , giving the kids a whole week off before ing on Monday, October .Schools break up for Christmas around Friday, December , .It is always best to check the Government or school website in your area to make sure you have the correct date.Term times and holidays y slightly across the country with non-pupil days - known as Professional Development days - being slotted in.Most schools publish their term dates on their websites, and councils will usually also provide the details online.In , its good to note that the May Day bank holiday has been moved to mark the th anniversary of VE Day.The bank holiday will now be on Friday, May , rather than Monday, May , .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: where hurricane dorian florida live path map
story: Florida has declared a state of emergency, and tourists have been asked to leave the Bahamas.High winds of the Category  hurricane are now sweeping through the islands of Abaco in the Bahamas.The Prime Minister of the archipelago, Hubert Minnis tweeted: Abaco now experiencing tropical storm force winds as #HurricaneDorian approaches, and will begin to feel hurricane force winds later this morning.Grand Bahama expected to feel tropical storm winds at am and hurricane force winds at pm.Praying for everyone’s safety.Minnis also urged residents to head for the main island to escape the devastating, dangerous storm.I want you to remember: homes, houses, structures can be replaced. Lives cannot be replaced, he said, adding that , people and , homes were at riskLATEST WEATHER NEWS" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" BLOW TORCH Hurricane Dorian could trigger a HEATWAVE in Britain this week – after cold snap " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" GREAT BRRITAIN Britain to be hit by chilly blast this week sending temps plunging to C " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   as-comp-weathers.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" FALL DROWN THREE MONTHS of rain as warm  wet autumn on way - but good news for next week " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" GOING DOWN A STORM Whats the dference between a typhoon, a cyclone and a hurricane  " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   car-.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" WET WET WET Flood warnings as torrential rain is set to batter Britain today With the storm set to hit the main holiday spot of Grand Bahama around am local timetoday, Sunday September , all tourists have been asked to leave.But forecasters cautioned that the storms track remains still highly uncertain and even a small deviation could put Dorian offshore or well inland.Forecasters say Dorian will threaten the Florida peninsula late Monday or early Tuesday.Millions of people in Florida, along with the states Walt Disney World and President Donald Trumps Mar-a-Lago resort, are in the potential cross hairs of the hurricane.Shoppers in Florida were seen queuing around blocks to buy supplies such as medication and fuel. The coastal city of Miami ordered the removal of electric rental scooters from the streets to avoid them becoming projectiles.A state of emergency has officially been declared in Florida.Dorians wind speeds put the storm among the most dangerous in recent history.Forecasters warned that it could be the US East Coasts worst since the category five Hurricane Andrew killed  people and destroyed , homes in .US President Donald Trump said he was monitoring Dorian, which he described as an extremely dangerous storm on Twitter. He cancelled a planned trip to Poland, sending Vice-President Mike Pence in his place.Dorian is the fth in s Atlantic hurricane season.A tropical storm is a spiral arrangement of thunderstorms.Depending on its location and strength, a tropical storm is referred to as a hurricane, typhoon, cyclone or simply a tropical storm.By the middle of the week, Tropical Storm Dorian is expected to strengthen into a hurricane, when the winds go over mph.Its heading towards Florida where a state of emergency has been declared.Disney World and other attractions are in the path.The big cruise lines, operating out of Miami, have begun rerouting their ships.Jessica Armesto and her one-year-old daughter, Mila, had planned to have breakfast with Minnie Mouse, Donald Duck and Goofy at Disney World.But instead, the mum decided to take shelter at her mothers hurricane-resistant house in Miami with its kitchen full of nonperishable foods.She said: It felt like it was better to be safe than sorry, so we cancelled our plans.The storm gained media attention towards the beginning of this week when it was east-southeast of Barbados and heading towards the Caribbean.The UK foreign office has warned those travelling to Florida.A statement says: A state of emergency has been declared in Florida.The US National Hurricane Center predicts Dorian reaching Category  Hurricane strength before weakening. High winds and rainfall from intense thunderstorms are anticipated. You should monitor the progress of approaching storms on the US National Hurricane Centre and follow instructions issued by the local authorities, including any evacuation orders.

title: prince andrew must not duck epstein questions
story: While the rest of the Royal Family go out of their way to be polite and pleasant to us mere peasants, he appeared to take great joy in making me feel uncomfortable. Well, now it’s his turn to squirm.I have no idea of his exact involvement with the hideous pervert Jeffrey Epstein during their “friendship”, but this week one of Epstein’s alleged victims claimed she had sex with Andrew three times. Virginia Roberts, photographed being embraced by the prince when she was a teenager, claimed he “knows exactly what he has done” and should “come clean” about it.The waters are being muddied with claims by “friends” of Andrew the photo is fake. He strenuously denies any wrongdoing but this story is not going to go away and people are demanding answers.Epstein hanged himself in his New York jail cell this month while on sex-trafficking charges — and sparked conspiracy theories galore.Andrew claims he knew nothing about Epstein’s disgusting lestyle, but it is baffling that he continued to associate with him even after Epstein’s conviction in  for procuring an underage girl for prostitution, making him a registered sex offender.Why on Earth would anyone continue to hang out with such an unsavoury character, especially , like Andrew, you are a dad with two daughters of your own  At the very least this scandal shows that Andrew has appalling judgment when it comes to his pals and associates.He has previous when it comes to cosying up to the rich and dubious. Questions were asked when Andrew sold his run-down “Southyork” mansion to a Kazakh oligarch in  for millions over the asking price.MOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   as-comp-kav.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTrevor Kavanagh If only Remainer rabble would see the light like Archbishop of Canterbury " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   Tm-comp-Hammond-Bojo-v.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Tory Remainers arent trying to protect jobs, theyre trying to stop Brexit " data-srcset"https:i.wp www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT-.jpg croppx%Cpx%Cpx%Cpxresize%Cssl" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Jeremy Corbyn and panic-stricken Remainers are now resorting to blatant lies " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN ON SUNDAY SAYS Emmanuel Macron is now bending as European fears about No Deal grow " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   TM-comp-Ian-Duncan.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentIAIN DUNCAN SMITH Corbyns hate mob are the ones staging a coup with anti-Brexit marches " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   tp-composite-james-forsyth.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentJAMES FORSYTH Its rogue ones vs. prorogue ones as MPs fight to seize control of Brexit Again, he denied any wrongdoing and the scandal went away. That might not be the case this time around. He’s very lucky that the Queen continues to stand by him. Andrew is always cited as her favourite child and Her Majesty accepts her son’s vehement denials when it comes to Epstein.He also has the full support of ex-we Sarah Ferguson, who knows all too well what it is like to be caught up in a scandal. She was apparently financially “assisted” by Epstein, something she now regrets.Sarah and Andrew have been lying low on holiday together, sparking rumours they are back together. But even this odd couple realised Andrew playing his usual rounds of golf in the Spanish sunshine looked callous.They are back for “crisis talks” and I don’t envy the royal advisers who have to try to spin this one. No one is saying Andrew has committed any sort of crime, but anything that has Epstein’s grubby fingerprints all over it inevitably reeks to high heaven.And the Prince has done his reputation irreparable harm by his association with such a contemptible sexual predator. We are light years away from the dashing young prince who won the respect and admiration of the British public for his role in the Falklands War.He has never reached the heady heights of that level of popularity since, and clearly he never will again. But he could redeem himself by at least being willing to answer questions from investigators in the States.Being a royal should not mean he is above helping law enforcement. It might be embarrassing and uncomfortable — butAndrew has done nothing wrong, he has nothing to worry about.NEVER mind the nights drawing in, you know our summer days are numbered when Strictly rears its sequinned head. This year has the potential to be a classic.I always look forward to seeing the celebs step into the spray tan booth, embrace the glitz and rhinestones and unleash their inner as. But my ones-to-watch this year have actually already found theirs.Michelle Visage from Ru Paul’s Drag Race and ex-Corrie star Catherine Tyldesley both have big personalities, raucous laughs and are women after my own heart.Michelle has been very open about her struggles with an eating disorder, and recently had her breast implants removed due to health concerns. She’s a fierce campaigner for more understanding about the side-effects of breast enhancement ops.Catherine has always wanted to be a dancer but said this week that being overweight as a youngster scuppered her chances of tripping the light fantastic.She famously lost st and promotes sensible eating and exercise as the only way to shed weight, which is something I’ve been banging on about forever. Both are at the top of their game and raring to go.They will burn up the dancefloor and provide us with some memorable moments . . .  but as they are both happily married, these will all thankfully be Strictly confined to the ballroom floor.WHAT in the name of Rule Britannia is going on with British Airways  They are lurching from crisis to crisis, with computer glitches and strikes almost becoming the norm.Last week I had to cancel a long-awaited trip to Orkney because of the proposed industrial action next month by BA pilots, after receiving an email to say my flight had been axed. With a heavy heart, I apologetically cancelled the glorious Foveran Hotel, our car hire and the babysitter for our dog son Angus.The next day another computer-generated email popped up telling me that actually the flight wasn’t cancelled after all. Oops, and all that. Now I’ve been trying to get some clarity from the BA hotline for days – with no joy.I’m reluctant to rebook everything in case it all goes t*ts-up again and they cancel the flights for a second time. It’s infuriating, stressful and upsetting. Behind every cancelled or delayed flight are heartbreaking stories of people missing weddings, hospital visits, funerals and job interviews.Can I stress emphatically that, in my experience, BA staff at the check-in coal face, who have to deal with distraught and angry passengers when flights are cancelled or delayed, deserve a blinking medal for their patience and forbearance in dealing with the recent avalanche of almighty management cock-ups.Likewise, those battling valiantly in customer service, and all of the stalwart cabin crew, especially those with years of experience who are unfailingly professional, caring and kind.They are being as badly let down as us passengers, and it’s depressing to see a once proud and noble British brand shooting itself in the foot.Those at the very top really don’t deserve their hardworking staff and they also have to stop taking us customers for granted.NORMALLY I view those “scientic studies” about the benefits or detriments of certain food and drink with folded arms and a very sceptical: “Aye, right.”It might, however, be worth paying attention to the very latest one which concludes that red wine really is good for you.We already knew about the benefits for your heart, but now it turns out red wine could improve digestion and protect you against issues with high cholesterol.I reckon the men and women in white lab coats have a point.Cheers!I’VE been lucky enough to have spent the past couple of weeks travelling around Rajasthan in India.I happily scoffed some form of curry three times a day for every meal and guzzled very impressive Indian wine.I’m now addicted to dosa with daal and spicy mint sauce for breakfast – followed throughout the day by chilli paneer and laal maas all washed down with endless cups of masala tea.Halfway through the trip, I rather naively posted a snap of myself, right, taken by the pool during our stay in Shahpura Bagh, on the way to Jodhpur. It showed that my excess holiday baggage had mainly landed around my tummy.Some people were very kind about my -year-old unfiltered, non- Photoshopped body, my make-up-free face and flyaway hair. Others not so much.All I wanted to do was show that you don’t have to be body perfect to wear a bikini and smile in the sunshine when you are on holiday.We shouldn’t feel embarrassed about a few lumps and bumps or scars and blemishes and we need to stop beating ourselves up all the time and learn to celebrate our so-called flaws. Le really is too short.SHAME on all of those chortling at little Prince George because he is taking ballet lessons. I’m sure none of the mockers have ever actually met a male ballet dancer.Those fellas are as tough as nails.They can beat a bully into a pulp with one flick of their sinewy wrists. They are mentally and physically fiercely strong.I can’t think of a better way for the future king to learn discipline, teamwork and how to push himself to the limit. All of you sniggering in the back should grow the hell up.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rogue ones vs the prorogue ones
story: MPs willfrom their summer break on Tuesday and anti-No Deal members will immediately try to seize control of the order paper, allowing them to determine what gets debated in the Commons and when. With the connivance of the Speaker John Bercow, they will almost certainly succeed.Having gained this power, they will set about binding Boris Johnson’s hands. They will try to legislate to ensure this country cannot leave the European Union without a deal.Do they have the numbers to pull this off  Probably, yes.The ranks of Tory rebels have been swelled by the arrival of former Cabinet ministers such as Philip Hammond and David Gauke, and the Government’s decision to prorogue Parliament means that plans to wait until the end of September to act have been dropped.One former minister says the “prorogation scandal has tipped things over the edge”.If they have the numbers, do they have the time  This is more doubtful.No’s decision to prorogue Parliament means they would have to get a bill through both Houses in just over a week. With Bercow’s help, it will be possible for them to rush it through the Commons quickly. But it will be much harder to do that in the Lords.MOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   as-comp-kav.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTrevor Kavanagh If only Remainer rabble would see the light like Archbishop of Canterbury " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   Tm-comp-Hammond-Bojo-v.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Tory Remainers arent trying to protect jobs, theyre trying to stop Brexit " data-srcset"https:i.wp www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT-.jpg croppx%Cpx%Cpx%Cpxresize%Cssl" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Jeremy Corbyn and panic-stricken Remainers are now resorting to blatant lies " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN ON SUNDAY SAYS Emmanuel Macron is now bending as European fears about No Deal grow " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   TM-comp-Ian-Duncan.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentIAIN DUNCAN SMITH Corbyns hate mob are the ones staging a coup with anti-Brexit marches One Brexit-backing former Secretary of State tells me: “Our lot down there will do their best to talk it out.”Eventhe rebels can get a bill passed, the Government’s actions this week are designed to show that they won’t simply comply with it. They want the rebels to think they can’t succeed unless they change the government. “The aim is to force a binary choice between Corbyn and our Brexit plan,” is how one of those at the heart of things explains it.Those close to Boris Johnson believe this is their best chance of getting things through. They calculate that, ultimately, the Commons will not be prepared to take the risk of making Jeremy Corbyn prime minister.This is a high-risk manoeuvre. But so far, the thought of putting Corbyn in No even temporarily has proved too much for all but a couple of the Tory rebels.At the same time, Boris is trying to reassure Tory MPs that he really is trying for a deal. I understand that next week, Amber Rudd — the Work and Pensions Secretary who campaigned for Remain in  — will join with him as part of an effort to persuade Tory MPs not to back the rebel legislation, and to give him time to secure a deal.I am told she was “disappointed” by his decision to prorogue but remains convinced he is genuine about getting a deal and that the EU will offer concessionsParliament backs the Government next week.The biggest problem with the extension the rebels want is they can’t say what it is for. The reason is they can’t agree on what its purpose should be: Many want to stop Brexit altogether, others just to block No Deal.An extension without a purpose would do nothing but prolong the uncertainty and keep this country in limbo. It is time to get on with it.Why, because No think most voters just want Brexit done, so they want to be talking about the public’s priorities.They think they win whenever Boris is seen on the news discussing these issues. The polls suggest the PM is having some success with this approach. One Secretary of State puts the current Tory poll lead down to BoJo being: “Very effective at giving them hope of a non-Brexit dominated world.”Of course, another reason why the PM wants to keep hammering home his domestic priorities is that we are going to end up having a general election in the next few months.l IN another sign that a general election is coming, I am informed that the Scottish Tories will not select their new leader until AFTER such a poll.The decision to stick with an interim leader following Ruth Davidson’s resignation suggests the  hierarchy north of the border doesn’t think there is  time to have a proper leadership contest before any general election.We will clearly all be heading to the polling station sooner, rather than later.ANY Tory MP who votes for the extension legislation next week will not be allowed to stand as a Tory candidate at the next election.I understand No have decided to treat next week’s votes as they would a confidence vote, with anyone not backing the Government being immediately disqualied from standing for the party again. They hope this will keep some Tory waverers in the Government lobby next week.It would mean thatformer Cabinet ministers such as Philip Hammond voted for the legislation, as they intend to, they would be barred from standing for the party again, ending their time as Tory MPs.  It is hard to think of a precedent for so many Tories going from being Cabinet ministers to being ineligible to stand for the party.This upping of the stakes will certainly have an effect on some Tory MPs. There will be those who are reluctant to end their careers in the party over this issue.There will undoubtedly be protests over this decision. Boris Johnson will be accused of purging the Tory party of those opposed to No Deal. But the tactics are not dissimilar to those used by John Major to get the Maastricht Treaty through in  in the face of opposition from his party’s Eurosceptics.This approach is not without risk, though. There is a danger  MPs will still rebel  then decide  they have nothing left to lose, increasing not only the chances of them voting down the Government in a no-confidence vote, but also backing an alternative prime minister.Currently, only about ten per cent of Home Office grants to charities go to those with an income of less than £million a year, compared to the sixty-odd per cent which goes to those with an income of £million plus a year.The new Home Secretary, Priti Patel, has been impressed by the efforts of charities such as OnSide, which work to keep kids off the street.One ally of the Home Secretary says that more police and greater stop and search powers are, “only one side of the coin”,  in terms of dealing with kne crime and that “there are lots of kids with nothing to do and that’s a big reason so many are falling in with the wrong crowd and getting into trouble.“There are some great small charities out there giving them a purpose beyond a le of crime, and they deserve more support.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: real friends screen kids happy karren brady
story: Almost a quarter of a million kids in the UK — around , — report being unhappy with their lives as a whole, according to The Children’s Society.This is partly due to increasing loneliness and turbulent friendships. And guess what has been highlighted by charity experts as the main cause “Excessive social media use.”Anyone surprised by that either  Thought not.Of course, not all children are unhappy. But parents should take this news as a serious warning shot. Because when it comes to our children’s happiness, the trend is clearly going in the wrong direction.With social media, the problem is partly one of expectations.Most grown-ups are seasoned enough to take the inevitable “my perfect le” posts on Instagram with a pinch of salt.MOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   as-comp-kav.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTrevor Kavanagh If only Remainer rabble would see the light like Archbishop of Canterbury " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   Tm-comp-Hammond-Bojo-v.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Tory Remainers arent trying to protect jobs, theyre trying to stop Brexit " data-srcset"https:i.wp www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT-.jpg croppx%Cpx%Cpx%Cpxresize%Cssl" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Jeremy Corbyn and panic-stricken Remainers are now resorting to blatant lies " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN ON SUNDAY SAYS Emmanuel Macron is now bending as European fears about No Deal grow " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   TM-comp-Ian-Duncan.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentIAIN DUNCAN SMITH Corbyns hate mob are the ones staging a coup with anti-Brexit marches " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   tp-composite-james-forsyth.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentJAMES FORSYTH Its rogue ones vs. prorogue ones as MPs fight to seize control of Brexit Butyou are new to these things, being bombarded with images on your mate’s Instagram page of the le you are “meant” to be living could make even the most secure children begin to feel inadequate.The other problem is that it’s always “on” — and so are our kids. It used to be that children could shut the front door on a day of school and leave it on the outside until morning. Now, though, there is -hour access.Another news story this week revealed that nine out of ten teens aren’t getting enough sleep or exercise. It doesn’t take a genius to link the two issues.Social media — and reality TV — also reveal a new emphasis on appearance that has changed so much in the past  years, for adults as well as children. It’s just that children are more susceptible to that pressure.Other things have changed too — not least our approach to parenting . We are much more child-focused, which isn’t a bad thing necessarily.But telling our kids they are the best, no matter what they do, risks them thinking they are the best without doing anything at all to be so.Yes, we can help boost our children’s self-esteem. But what we should really do is help them boost their own self-esteem by doing things that make them feel good about themselves.Obviously, more families now have two parents in the workplace. That is a good thing but perhaps some working parents feel the need to compensate for their absence in ways — such as too many screens and “treats” — that aren’t necessarily brilliant for their children’s mental health.I write as a mother of two who worked more or less throughout my children’s young lives.I’m proud to say we all made it through in one piece.Obviously, I am no parenting expert. And I’m not claiming to have the answer to the world’s ills.But over the years, I’ve identied three golden rules I believe build a foundation for happy kids.The first is sport. I passionately believe that being part of a team, having regular exercise, being out and about and maintaining a routine offers kids stability and boundaries.It helps children feel good about their bodies and their abilities, boosting their self-esteem.The second is friendship. I am talking about proper friendship — not Facebook “friends” you never meet. When kids leave their phones at home and develop real friendships, they find people they can talk to and have fun with.Never underestimate the importance of fun. The third golden rule is probably the most important. Keep talking.There are too many tragic examples recently of young people who felt it necessary to take their own lives. I believe a problem shared is a problem halved. No matter how bad something is, talking always helps.I don’t remember ever reading about suicide when I was younger — especially not suicide in young people. Now it is the biggest cause of death among people aged  to  and it affects three times more men than women. That is a scary statistic.The causes are complicated but we need to keep channels of communication open with our kids. That way,they are unhappy, we will know about it. Andwe know about it, we at least have the potential to help.Remember Alfie Patten  For a while, in , he was known as the nation’s youngest father at the age of just .Then he found out, later that year, that it was another boy who had made his -year-old girlfriend pregnant. So Alfie was off the hook.That should have left him with the feeling that he had dodged a bullet.It could have spurred him on towards getting a good education and a job, to building himself a future.The adults in his le should have encouraged him to do just that.Instead, this week he turned up at Lewes Crown Court to be sentenced after being convicted of criminal damage.The court heard he is now a jobless alcoholic who lives at home with his mother and has a history of criminal offences.He already had a -month suspended prison sentence hanging over his head after being convicted on June  of shoplting, theft and possession of an imitation firearm.This is a good reminder that suspended sentences do not work. Alfie Patten clearly needs a bigger wake-up call than a suspended sentence or he risks ending up dead from alcohol and drugs.I saw a bench in my local park the other day that said: “Die with memories . . .  not dreams.”So true. But this guy, who is creating all the wrong sorts of memories, is a nightmare.Well, I don’t know about you but I am filled with relief that the heatwave – and even summer – is over.The cooler weather is perfect timing for going back to school and back to work, so we can all concentrate again. Hot weather is great when you are lying around in swimwear next to a pool . . .  notyou are sitting in a classroom or office.I  loved the photos of Dame Joan Collins, , lined up with the other stars of the Charlotte Tilbury makeup campaign.What a lady. Joan, is classy, funny and damn stylish. Or as my nan would’ve said, well turned out.Another day, another story about taxpayers’ money being wasted in foreign aid.This week it emerged that classrooms in nearly  schools in Pakistan – paid for by us – have been closed because they were badly built and unsafe.The buildings were erected as part of a £million aid project and their closure has left , children taking lessons outdoors or in overcrowded rooms.So, presumably, back where they were in the first place. On the upside, this has prompted some MPs to call for an inquiry about how our annual foreign aid budget – around £billion – is spent.On the downside, this is an example of yet more foreign aid money that has fallen into the wrong hands and ended up being wasted.In the meantime, British schools are crying out for investment.So why are we spending money on Pakistani schools and not our own Meanwhile, in the UK, overseas patients have left the NHS with more than £million in unpaid bills for treatment, it emerged this week. That cash could pay for , nurses, , heart bypasses or nearly , junior doctors.Two London hospitals are owed £million each, including almost £, from one patient alone.Apparently staff are reluctant to chase payments, with doctors’ leaders saying their obligation to charge overseas patients is “racist” and deters vulnerable groups from seeking help.To me, that sounds completely bonkers.I don’t understand why you are not asked to produce your NHS number – we all have one – when you get to hospital.Every other country asks, so why not us It’s a national service, not an international one.Former Big Brother contestant Kate Lawler is campaigning to remove the taboo facing women who don’t want children.She said she considers her two dogs, Baxter and Shirley, as her family and she’s very content with that.She’s right, of course. Whether or not you want children comes down to personal choice and it should be fine for women not to want them.The only problem with her situation, though, is that her fiancé is “desperate” for children, which doesn’t sound so good.I think the most important thing when choosing whether or not to have kids with someone is the pair of you both being on the same page. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: benefits mum kids wales epilepsy autism
story: Bethan Carter, , is mum to five girls and six boys whose ages range from three to .Six of her kids are under the age of ten.Bethan lives with nine of her children in Briton Ferry, near Port Talbot, Wales, along with her husband Andy while two of her kids have since left home.Andy is dad to seven of the youngsters.Bethan struggles with severe epilepsy as well as severe memory loss due to a brain cyst and a malformation at the base of her brain.She also has three kids who suffer from epilepsy and her son Mark, , has severe autism and epilepsy and has several seizures a week.Bethan said: People judge me because I am on benefits, but unless you have a severely autistic child you cant know what it is like.I am happy with my family - I do not care what people say. They are happy and get the care they need.They are loved. I find it very rewarding to be a mum.Being a mum of so many kids is hard but I love it - they are all so loving.Mark has several seizures a week. Bethan said: When he fits, he just collapses and, when he comes out of a fit, he screams. He can not handle the little ones and likes being on his own.Usually Bethan gets up at around am to prepare breakfast for everyone and sort out all the medication for the day and ensure everyone gets the correct ones.Teenager Mark gets picked up by a taxi to take him to school in Bryncoch while Bethan and Andy then do the school run in two cars for the rest.While the kids are at school Bethan then spends her time cleaning and tidying the house.After the children have all been picked up from school Bethan will then start on dinner.She said:  I can not cook so I just try to make things quickly like beans or sausages.I try to have dinner ready shortly after they get back from school.If it has been a long day and it is getting late, we will get a KFC or a McDonalds.The family say they have fast food once or twice a week with each of these meals costing up to £.They also do a big monthly food shop at Farm Foods which costs £. This includes around £ on sausages and six boxes of  fish fingers for £.Some how they manage to fit it all in their two chest freezers and a fridge freezer.We get frozen food mainly because it is cheaper and more convenient, Bethan said. It is what they want.The family go through three big boxes of washing powder every month.With two washing machines and two dryers, there is washing on all the time and, with two bathrooms, Bethan can wash three of the children at a time in the shower downstairs.Time flies and before you know it is bed time again, she said. After dinner, they just play - there are toys everywhere.I try to get them to sleep by pm or pm. I am up until midnight or am doing things around the house.There are little breaks for the family as they never go on holidays, partly because Mark doesnt like it.If we go anywhere, we go somewhere for the day - normally Porthcawl, Bethan said. But it takes a lot of planning.It is hard work to have that many children, but they are happy and they are very close to each other.I am happy I got sterilised but I do not regret anything.The mum-of- said she worked full-time in a café until she had Mark  years ago.She quit her job to look after him and now relies on benefits to live. With £ coming in every two weeks, the benefits they receive include income support and child benefit, as well as disability allowance.It is not enough. I could take them all to town and spend £ just on shoes for all of them. We do not have any savings - all we have goes on them. We spend all year saving for Christmas.At the moment, the family live in a five-bedroom house in Briton Ferry, with three of the girls sleeping in one bedroom and three boys in another. The youngest one sleeps in the parents bedroom and then Mark and Amy - the two oldest - have their own rooms.Bethan and Andy met  years ago through an advert in the South Wales Evening Post.Andy said: I like having that many kids, it is always busy - it is non-stop.People can judge me as much as they want but I do not care.The family have recently been having problems with the roof over their back bedroom, which recently collapsed during a spell of bad weather.A lot of water started coming through and the family was told a new roof was needed.Andy said some temporary measures have been in place by housing association Tai Tarian but the roof is still not fixed.He said Mark sleeps in the bedroom with the damaged ceiling and has had to sleep in a dferent room.Andy said Mark doesnt understand why he cant stay in his room and that they have had to buy a new mattress and bedding after the water came through the roof.I am worried the ceiling could collapse any time, he said. It is not secure at all how it is now - it is going to cave in the moment it rains even a little bit.The permanent solution has been planned in and the tenant has been made aware of all our intentions.”

Lives cannot be replaced, he said.He added that , people and , homes were at risk to storm surges.Still, dozens of people ignored evacuation orders, officials said, and they were warned that they were placing their lives in danger.The end could be fatal, said Samuel Butler, assistant police commissioner. We ask you, we beg you, we plead with you to get to a place of safety.Silbert Mills, owner of the Bahamas Christian Network, said trees and power lines were torn down in The Abaco Islands and some roads were impassable.The winds are howling like weve never, ever experienced before, said Mills, , who planned to ride out the hurricane with his family in the concrete home he built  years ago in central Abaco.Authorities closed some airports in the outlying islands, but the main international airport remains open on Sunday.This is a le-threatening situation, the NHC warned. Residents there should take immediate shelter. Do not venture into the eyeit passes over your location.The eye of the storm - now at the highest possible category - is expected to lay waste to the Abaco Islands before barrelling northwards to Florida and Georgia.Millions of people from Florida to North Carolina were bracing to seeDorian would make landfall in the US or veer north into the Atlantic Ocean after hitting the Bahamas.Even a glancing blow from one of the strongest storms ever to menace Florida could bring torrential rains and damaging winds.Bahamas residents have already reported trees snapping and docks being destroyed before the brunt of the storm arrived.On Great Guana Cay, just off Great Abaco Island, waves began washing over low-lying parts of the tiny nine-mile strand of land.Although some residents left for Nassau and where days ago, some  to  are riding out the storm on the island.US President Donald Trump warned on Sunday that the storm would likely impact the eastern seaboard from Florida to North Carolina.Mr Trump later tweeted: Pray for the people in the Bahamas. Being hit like never before, Category . Almost  MPH winds.It is expected to make landfall on Floridas eastern coast before spinning through Georgia and South Carolina.According to tracking site FlightAware,  flights to, from or within America were cancelled on Saturday.And as of this morning another  planes were grounded for US trips scheduled for Sunday.The site said: “We expect these numbers to increase in the upcoming days, especially at airports in the region where Dorian is to make landfall.”Airlines have been issuing waivers to customers for several days for journeys which are heading to destinations in the hurricane’s path, reports CNN.While travel firms have issued advisories to cities in Florida, Georgia and the Caribbean – more waiver options will be issued for the Carolinas as the massive storm moves northwards up the east coast.Radar shows the eye of Hurricane Dorian during a reconnaissance mission over the Atlantic OceanOperations at Orlando International Airport will be suspended at am Monday local time, according to an official statement.Miami International Airport and Fort Lauderdale International Airport have yet to confirm what action they will take and are monitoring the hurricane’s path, it has been reported.The storm shted its path and could graze Floridas coast and continue on to Georgia and North and South Carolina.And that’s the same route as Category  Matthew took three years ago – hugging the southern east coast of the country while still causing billions of dollars of damage.The killer hurricane devastated the four states bringing wind and flood damage, killing  and leaving millions without power.But Bryan Norcross, a senior hurricane specialist, told Florida Today that Dorian is moving even slower than Matthew which means it could wreak more havoc on the sunshine state.He said: “As it stands right now, coastal Florida has got to be ready for storm surge exceeding Matthew. And higher winds than Matthew. And heavier rain than Matthew.The Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale is based on a hurricanes sustained wind speed.Just be ready for that. We’re in a position where you’re talking three, four, five days in advance of what you have to be ready for.“The threat is real from the Treasure Coast throughout the Florida peninsula. The trend is somewhat favourable — though the danger is still high along the immediate coastline.”The devastation caused by Dorian could be made worse by exceptionally strong tides called King Tide -which makes coastal areas more vulnerable to flooding.The super-strength tide happens around the time as a full moon or new moon and this year the King Tides have already flooded neighbourhoods in Miami - and the most recent full moon was yesterday.The storms winds reached mph today - just mph shy of becoming a Category  hurricane.Winds are currently raging over the warm Atlantic waters and is inching towards the northwestern Bahamas, according to the US National Hurricane Center.The centre says the storms path is still unpredictable, but Georgia and the Carolinas are now at risk of strong winds and le-threatening storm surge.The hurricane has slowed down since Thursday as it was originally expected to make landfall by Sunday.The NHC still warned Florida residents to say on alert.They said: It should be noted that the new forecast track does not preclude Dorian making landfall on the Florida coast, as large portions of the coast remain in the track cone of uncertainty.Supermarket shelves have been left bare as residents scramble to prepare for the Category  storm.Floridians left supermarket shelves empty after grabbing water, bread and canned goods in the event power and water are cut off.At a Publix supermarket in Cocoa Beach, Ed Ciecirski of the customer service department said the pharmacy was extra busy with people rushing to fill prescriptions.Saturday: Dorian is expected to slow its forward motion and will likely begin to impact the northwestern Bahamas with tropical storm-force winds by Saturday night.Sunday: Dorians hurricane siege will begin in the northwest Bahamas as it continues to slow down. Tropical storm-force winds may begin to arrive in parts of Florida. Large swells should begin to arrive at the coast from North Carolina to Florida.Monday: Dorian may still be hammering the northwest Bahamas as it crawls slowly. Bands of rain, strong winds may affect parts of Florida. How strong the winds will be depends on how close the center of Dorian is to the Florida coast, which is uncertain at this time.Tuesday-Thursday: Dorian is expected to move north, then northeast near the coasts of Florida, Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina. The exact track is very uncertain, ranging from a track far enough offshore to keep hurricane force winds away from land, to a landfall anywhere in this zone.Friday-Next Saturday: Dorian is then expected to race off the Northeast Seaboard, but could track close enough to bring rain and some wind to the Virginia Tidewater, Nantucket, Marthas Vineyard and Cape Cod, before it heads toward the Canadian Maritimes by next weekend.The grocery was rationing bottled water and had run out of dry ice.Homeowners and businesses rushed to cover their windows with plywood.Tfany Miranda of Miami Springs, Florida said: I feel helpless because the whole coast is threatened.What’s the use of going all the way to Georgiait can land there You never know with these hurricanes. It could be good, it could be bad. You just have to be prepared.Jeremy Kichler, a University of Georgia extension agent in Colquitt County who works with local farmers, told local news: A lot of folks are still recovering from Irma two years ago and Michael last year.I don’t knowwe can stand another one.Ron DeSantis, the governor, said the Florida Highway Patrol would begin escorting fuel trucks to help them get past the lines of waiting motorists and replenish gas stations.On Friday, the National Hurricane Center said Dorian had just reached extremely dangerous Category  status with winds already clocking  mph .The first mandatory evacuation orders were carried out this morning.Residents in Bred County have been told to start leaving at am on Sunday The Weather Channel reports.Coastal areas could get  to  inchesof rain, with  inchesin some places, triggering le-threatening flash floods, the hurricane center said.FEMA official Jeff Byard said Dorian is likely to create a lot of havoc for roads, power and other infrastructure.

story: Cops smashed the windows to rescue the poor pooch trapped in a cage with the windows shut in Bridlington, East Yorks, today.Humberside Police said they had to break into the car parked just metres away from a red sign which read: Warning, dogs must not be left in vehicles or you may be prosecuted. title: remainer rabble archbishop of canterbury brexit
story: The left-wing, pro-Brussels, anti-No Deal prelate wants ­fellow Remainers to “stop whingeing” and accept the  referendum.It is a Damascene conversion for Dr Justin Welby.Last week he was preparing to lead a “citizens’ forum” against a clean-break Brexit.If only puce-faced boobies like Owen Jones, Stephen Fry and Hugh Grant would follow suit and stop throwing their rattles out of the pram.Along with the raving loony Labour Party and Tory ­hypocrite Sir John Major, who should know better.I used to think John Major was a well-intentioned cove, for all his failures as Prime Minister.He was roasted for trying to scrap the Pound, signing the Maastricht blueprint for a ­federal Europe — and ­suspending Parliament in the same way he now condemns as “fundamentally ­unconstitutional”.“Decent” Major emerges as a charlatan and hypocrite who is prepared to bring down a Tory PM struggling to deliver the will of the ­people — and replace it with a Marxist-led ­Labour ­rabble.Along with Phil Hammond and Dominic Grieve, he is willing to inflict terminal ­damage on the same British constitution and wreck public trust in Parliamentary ­democracy.It was Parliament whose MPs voted overwhelmingly for an In-Out referendum.It was Parliament that voted for every step towards Brexit along the way.It was Parliament that three times rejected the only EU deal on offer.And it was in Parliament, as Foreign Secretary in , that Phil Hammond lectured MPs on the paramount right of voters to choose — whatever the result of the ­referendum, saying it would be decided “not [by] Whitehall bureaucrats, certainly not ­Brussels Eurocrats, not even by government ministers or ­parliamentarians in this ­chamber. The decision must be for the common sense of the British people.”That decision was duly taken in the biggest single-issue democratic vote in British history.Hammond has been fighting ever since to turn it on its head.This is the real constitutional outrage. A defeated rump of Remainers, egged on by blatantly biased Commons Speaker John Bercow, is using every Parliamentary trick to destroy Brexit.Some threaten to occupy Parliament until dragged out by police.Left-wing class warriors will infuriate voters by blocking bridges and highways and stopping them getting to work.John Major and meddling Gina Miller have launched a Supreme Court bid to block No Deal.These are petulant tantrums. And they will fail.There is no chance Brussels will budge on the backstop, says chief negotiator Michel Barnier. In which case we simply drt across the October  deadline and out of the EU forever.There will be an election and Boris Johnson will win.The Tories already lead Labour by - per cent in the polls. title: hurricane dorian disney bahamas castaway cay cruise
story: The Category  hurricane hit Marsh Harbour in the Abaco Islands with mph winds on Sunday after officials made pleas to evacuate.Disney’s private island, Castaway Cay, which lies  miles south of Marsh Harbour, was not fully evacuated, despite being in the path of the storm.Disney confirmed that staff members are “being taken care of” in a storm shelter, which is stocked with food and water.But concerned relatives have taken to social media to ask why the staff were not evacuated from the island and taken to safety.Meg Green confirmed to SunOnline that her sister is stuck on the island.She tweeted: Remember that time Disney Cruise left  employees on a tiny island in a Category  hurricane  I do. They took shelter around pm.“They shouldn’t be in that situation. Why risk the lives of  staff members  They had plenty of time to evacuate, but the decision was made to stay“They were stuck and had faith in being evacuated. Families had faith, but you did nothing to get them off.“We don’t know why they would risk the safety of the staff in such a manner.Castaway Cay is a private island and an exclusive port for Disney Cruise Line.Only  of the , acres of the island are being used, but about  cruise line permanent residents live there.A spokesman for Disney confirmed to SunOnline: “Some of our Crew remained on the island and their care and safety is our highest priority.“We are in regular contact with island leadership, who is making sure our Crew is well taken care of in our storm shelter, which is designed for these types of situations.”Disney said Castaway Cay remains south of the more signicant weather and is currently experiencing “tropical storm force winds”.Hurricane Dorian made landfall in the Bahamas on Sunday afternoon, snapping trees, ripping the roofs off homes and sending waves crashing onto the street.Its devastating, said Joy Jibrilu, director general of the Bahamas Ministry of Tourism and Aviation.There has been huge damage to property and infrastructure. Luckily, no loss of le reported.With its maximum sustained winds of  mph and gusts up to  mph, Dorian tied the record for the most powerful Atlantic hurricane ever to come ashore.It equals the Labor Day hurricane of , before the storms were named.There were indications that the slow-moving Dorian would veer sharply northeastward after passing the Bahamas and track up the U.S. Southeast seaboard.But officials warned that evenits core did not make U.S. landfall, the potent storm would likely hammer the coast with powerful winds and heavy surf.South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster ordered a mandatory evacuation of the entire coast of the state amid Dorians threat.The order, which covers about , people, goes into effect at noon Monday, when state troopers will begin reversing lanes so they all head inland on major coastal highways.We cant make everybody happy, McMaster said. But we believe we can keep everyone alive.Authorities in Florida also ordered mandatory evacuations in some vulnerable coastal areas.More than  Labor Day flights in the U.S. had been cancelled as of Sunday afternoon, many of them in Florida as Dorian barrelled toward the states coast.The only recorded storm that was more powerful was Hurricane Allen in , with  mphwinds. That storm did not make landfall at the strength.Catastrophic conditions were reported in Abaco, with a storm surge of - feet , and Dorian was expected to cross Grand Bahama later in the day with all its fury, the centre said.The hurricane was moving to the west at  mph .In the northern stretches of the archipelago, hotels closed, residents boarded up homes and officials hired boats to move people to bigger islands.One video showed floodwaters rushing through the streets of an unidentied town at nearly the height of a car roof.In some parts of Abaco, you cannot tell the dference as to the beginning of the street versus where the ocean begins, said Prime Minister Hubert Minnis.According to the Nassau , he called it probably the most sad and worst day of my le to address the Bahamian people.Earlier, Minnis had warned that anyone who did not evacuate was in extreme danger and can expect a catastrophic consequence.The government opened  shelters across the Bahamas. Dozens ignored evacuation orders, officials said.The end could be fatal, said Samuel Butler, assistant police commissioner. We ask you, we beg you, we plead with you to get to a place of safety.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIndustry chiefs have savaged Tory Michael Goveaposs categorically untrue claim there will be no food shortages in a no-deal Brexit. Mr Gove - who is in charge of planning for no-deal - promised today that everyone will have the food they need after October .The Cabinet Office minister added: No, there will be no shortages of fresh food. But Mr Goveaposs claims were blasted as categorically untrue by the British Retail Consortium, which represents more than , firms.A spokesman said: It is categorically untrue that the supply of fresh food will be unaffected under a no deal Brexit.The retail industry has been crystal clear in its communications with Government over the past  months that the availability of fresh foods will be impacted as a result of checks and delays at the border.Indeed, the Government’s own assessments showed that the flow of goods through the channel crossings could be reduced by -% from day , as would the “availability and choice” of some foods. The slapdown came after Mr Gove also admitted some food prices look set to rise in a no-deal Brexit.     Mr Gove admitted: There are a number of economic factors in play. Some prices may go up. Other prices will come down.” A leaked document from the governmentaposs Operation Yellowhammer predicted some supplies of fresh food will fallthe UK crashes out without a deal on Halloween . The document said while there would not be an overall shortage of food, there would be less availability and choice, affecting vulnerable groups. Meanwhile, the government has already publicly warned school leaders they could have to substitute ingredients in pupilsapos dinners. As a result, councils are bracing for school dinners to become more expensive, as well as the risk nutrition standards will be changed. Pressed by the BBC today on whether there would be shortages of fresh food in no-deal, Mr Gove at first refused to answer. Instead he said: Everyone will have the food they need. When asked for a second time by interviewer Andrew Marr, he said: No, there will be no shortages of fresh food. But the BRC spokesman said: The BRC’s own assessment has shown that soft fruits and vegetables, such as strawberries, tomatoes and lettuces, would likely see reduced availability as they are largely imported during the winter months.  “While retailers continue to work with their suppliers to maintain stocks of non-perishable goods and plan ahead for any disruption caused by a no deal Brexit, it is impossible to mitigate it fully as neither retailers nor consumers can stockpile fresh foods. The reality remains that a no deal Brexit in October would present the worst of all worlds for our high streets and those who shop there. Retailers will be preparing for Christmas, stretching already limited warehousing capacity, and the UK will be importing the majority of its fresh food from the EU, magnying the impact of border delays.” It comes amid reports Mr Gove is planning to publish a heavily watered-down version of the original Yellowhammer warnings.    The document was presented to Cabinet ministers on around August , yet the Sunday Times reports officials are now making extensive changes to it before making it public. A Westminster source told the newspaper: This document is currently being neutralised, with all emotive language being stripped out. title: east germanys forgotten olympic doping
story: NewsEast Germany’s forgotten Olympic doping victims tell of illness, infertility and changing sexThe athletes say the terrible lelong problems they suffered after being fed steroids by the communist state are a warning to any sportsman who is tempted to cheatShareCommentsByJeremy Armstrong:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsVictim: Heidi Krieger lost her femininity to steroids"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShould Lord Coe want any reminder of the high price of tainted track and field glory, he need only talk to the forgotten victims of East Germany’s state-sponsored doping. Before the fall of the Berlin Wall, promising kids as young as eight were pumped full of steroids in a win-at-all-costs quest for victory. It brought more than  summer and winter Olympic medals between  and  – but at a terrible price. The stars of yesterday suffered severe depression, heart conditions, degenerative bone disease and infertility. Some even changed sex because of the drugs. Many spiralled into drink and drug addictions, unable to find work. Olympic legend Coe, , now head of the athletics world governing body the IAAF, was called to account this week in the wake of the Russian doping scandal. He told MPs on the Culture, Media and Sport committee: “I have the support of the sport. Have there been failures  Yes. Will I fix them  Yes.”  Maybe he will. But the sport has failed for years to stamp out cheating. And for East German athletes, the vast majority duped into taking drugs, that has meant ruined lives. GDR weightlter Roland Schmidt was pumped so full of steroids, he grew DD breasts. He had to have them surgically removed as his body had stopped producing testosterone. Shot putter Heidi Krieger suffered the opposite effect. Testosterone took her femininity. She changed sex and now lives as a man, teaching youngsters the dangers of pumping steroids in a bid for sporting glory. About , GDR former athletes who were given little blue pills have just celebrated a £.million pay-out from the German Government. After more than  years of suffering, it amounts to little more than £, per athlete.  But they are jubilant at their agony finally being recognised. Heidi took so many steroids she is now Andreas. Drugs she was forced to take by coaches as a young girl changed her gender and left her with pain in her hips and legs from lting huge weights while under the influence of steroids. Nicknamed Hormone Heidi by rivals, she had a full sex-change operation in , completing the physical change. Read more: Doping agency declares Russia and four other countries non-compliant Happily married to Ute Krause, a swimmer who was also a victim of the GDR system, Andreas shocks young people with photos of when he was Heidi. “The big dference these days is that the Russian athletes have a choice,” says Andreas, . “They will pay a terrible price in future. We had no choice because we were under a dictatorship.  “They told us they were vitamins, and we believed them. They exploited my love of sport. “Now I give something back by teaching young people. I tell them about Athlete , a woman who was given pills every day by her coach. “By , she had so many medals due to doping, but by  she was broken. Then I say ‘OK, Heidi can speak to you about doping – because Athlete  is me.’” It has quite an impact. He adds: “I understand Heidi better than ever today. When I see photos, I accept that was me. That is the secret, the first step. I did not hide my past. It is not worth it. She is part of me still.”  Communist East Germany struggled to provide basics for its people, yet wanted to show the world its power through its athletes. It wrecked their lives. Secret police files revealed they had been given Oral-Turinabol, a steroid produced by pharmaceutical firm Jenapharm. It was approved for some illnesses, but not meant as a performance enhancer. Heidi’s records show that in , the year in which she became European champion, she was given , milligrams of Oral-Turinabol. Read more: London  bosses told during Games their drug-testing procedures were aposaposappallingaposapos That is roughly , milligrams more than the amount given to Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson, whose doping programme shocked the world when it was exposed in . Jenapharm argued it was not culpable, since the drug was legal but misused by trainers. Then a state-owned company, subservient to the wishes of the Communist regime during the s and s, it produced an estimated two million tablets per year given to GDR athletes. Lawyers say files from East Germany’s notorious secret police, the Stasi, show that company officials had discussed the doping programme with the government. But Isabelle Roth, the company’s then chief executive, insisted the firm was not the “driving force” behind the doping programme. She said: “The drug was misused. We cannot be held responsible.”  Former GDR hammer thrower Thomas Gotze, , now a state prosecutor in Germany, was given so many pills as a teenager that he would work out for up to six hours. “I only found out later they were steroids,” he says. “Russians should come here to see how they will end up – broken, sick, injured. In  years, they will be just like us.” Ines Geipel, , part of a s world-beating East German sprint team and now a college lecturer, set up the group for GDR victims. She is unsure about Coe’s ability to clean up athletics. But she has a stark message for President Vladimir Putin and the Russian athletes prepared to sacrice everything for sporting glory: You will pay the price.  She says: “Putin needs great sporting success just as the GDR did. “It is more than  years ago now and yet there are so many parallels with the Russian situation and ours. It is about a state-controlled abuse. “It carried on until . We are probably talking about  to , athletes in total. We saw kids as young as eight being doped. They were guinea pigs and we have seen the health impact down the generations, passed from grandfather to grandchild. “The bodies are broken, and so are the souls. Naturally there was great gynaecological damage because the women were taking men’s hormones. We have seen still births, infertility, disabled children born to former athletes.”  Ines says young athletes were often trapped in special training camps. Some mums revolted when daughters ed with deep voices, muscles, facial hair. “Some managed to get out,” she says. “But most were too scared. You cannot imagine now what it was like to live under state control then. Athletes were alone, we could not talk to each other out of fear of being found out and punished.” Ex-GDR sprinter Marita Koch still holds the world record for the m,  years after she ran, but has always denied doping. Her time of .secs was set at the IAAF World Cup in Canberra, the last of her  inidual outdoor world records.

story: NewsGirl who lost both legs and arm from meningitis can now hi-five twin with new limb£, bionic  Hero Arm is giving triple amputee Riane Hedgecock a brilliant new lease of le - starting with high fiving her twin brotherShareCommentsByNathan Sandhu:,  SEP Updated:,  SEP NewsPictured with twin brother Rico, , brave triple amputee Rinae Hedgecock, , from Greater Manchester, gives him a high-five "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Rinae Hedgecock can already high-five her twin brother Rico and pick up a Coca-Cola bottle with her Hero Arm. The bionic limb is not available on the NHS but wellwishers donated the £, fee to a crowdfunding campaign in  hours. Her doting dad John, a bricklayer, said: “It’s le-changing. She cannot wait to get back to school to show it off to all her friends.” She is loving it and is proud as punch. She is absolutely chuffed. Her face lit up like a Christmas tree when she had it fitted. It has taken no time whatsoever for her to get used to the arm. She was virtually off and running in under an hour. She was grabbing things and high-fiving her brother. Itaposs the simple things that we take for granted. I never thought we would be where we are today. Itaposs not just the physical side of it. It was mental torture for her not being able to do certain things. Itaposs a le-changing moment for her. Itaposs simple to put the arm on which she can do herself. I want to thank everyone who has helped us get to where we are. You have no idea what this means to us all. Rinae said: “It’s amazing, because the things that I couldn’t do before, I can do them now.” She collapsed at home in Eccles, Greater Manchester, after playing with friends in April  and saying she started to fell like her body was aching.    Naturally, single-father John, a bricklayer, believed this was down to the activity and Rinae went to bed as usual. However, the next morning she woke up with an extreme temperature and John spotted blood blisters appearing on her skin. Medics at Alder Hey Hospital in Liverpool said she had just  hours to live. She battled back but lost both legs, her left arm below the elbow and the digits on her right hand. Rinae, who has a twin brother Rico and older sister Cha, , was in intensive care for six months while she battled the condition and recovered from multiple le-saving surgeries.She was hooked up to three machines pumping fresh blood around her body while she made her incredible recovery.Rinae has since undergone years of physiotherapy on her aposstumpsapos to allow her to use prosthetic legs and was later given a aposplastic armapos by the NHS.   However, the NHS-provided plastic arm had no ality and was likened to a mannequinaposs limb by her father. The Hero Arm, which is controlled by sensors that detect muscle movements, was fitted at Dorset Orthopaedic in ­Staffordshire last week. Samantha Payne, Co-founder and COO of Bristol-based manufacturer, Open Bionics, said: Weaposre thrilled to see Rinae receive her Hero Arm. Rinae crowdfunded for the device and was fitted through private healthcare, and she is one of dozens of people with upper limb dferences in the UK fundraising for a Hero Arm. We very much hope the NHS sees how helpful these devices are and will begin offering them to the people who need them. Weaposve worked really hard to achieve a price point for the device that is acceptable for existing NHS budgets for prosthetic provision.

On the morning of June , he said he was going for a walk, maybe only  minutes or perhaps longer, but not to worry.He said to take my bathers and book to the pool and that he would see me later. He took  Euros and a bottle of water and left at around .am. After he failed to , Gillian raised the alarm and a full scale search was carried out by the police. story: NewsopinionNada Farhoud: Our own future lies in the fate of Greenlands Inughuit peopleGreenlands Inughuit people have a unique way of le which now faces an unprecedented threat from global warmingShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  SEP NewsopinionIcebergs are melting and collapsing at an unprecedented rate in the Arctic "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Inughuit people have lived in the Arctic desert in the North West corner of ­Greenland for centuries. It’s the most northerly permanently inhabited settlement in the world. A thousand miles away from the capital Nuuk, they have survived in this remote corner by following ancient ways of le, using kayaks and harpoons to hunt narwhal in the summer and travelling by ­dog sled in the winter. But this unique way of le now faces an unprecedented threat – global warming. I spent a week living in this community in August to understand their precarious existence.    Many have relatives in the Canadian Arctic, where the Inughuit ­originate. Previously it was possible to travel across the Smith Soundon dog sled, but it’s now impossible as the sea ice disappears. The only option is to fly to ­Copenhagen, almost ,km away, and then to cross the Atlantic to Montreal – a journey few can afford. Their transition to a consumer society has been extremely rapid and has left a plethora of social problems in its wake, including, among others, the well-documented rampant alcoholism. It also has one of the highest suicide rates in the world. NASA has a semi-permanent presence here with satellites capturing the ice melt in real time. Ice stations have scientists from every G nation. The island’s ice sheet covers % of the land, km thick in places, and holds % of the world’s entire fresh water. The Jakobshavn glacier near Ilulissat – believed to be responsible for the iceberg that sank the Titanic – is so colossal that it alone has raised global sea levels by mm. It conveys more meltwater into the Atlantic in a day than London and New York use in a year. But why does this matter  The Arctic, along with Antarctic, is the early indicator of the impacts we can all expect to experience in the future.
